afabc458-87c3-4669-a6ab-c5e1ddcd807a.description: This eight-week course is designed to give MDOC Employment Transition Specialists knowledge of the eight Essential Employability Qualities - Effective Communication, Teamwork, Critical Analysis, Problem Solving, Learning & Adaptability, Motivation & Initiative, Professionalism & Responsibility, and Digital Literacy. Learners engage in lectures, discussions, writing exercises, presentations, and interviews with employers. Learners receive constructive feedback in all exercises.
afabc458-87c3-4669-a6ab-c5e1ddcd807a.name: Essential Employability Qualities, Missouri Department of Corrections

badge_template_activities.title: Participants engage in 18 hours of live, instructor-led class time, via Zoom, with the instructor. Once absence is allowed, with a short one-on-one makeup class.

After reading about Knowles' Adult Learning Theory, participants select one of the six presented theories and author a one-page writeup on that topic. Participants receive detailed edits and feedback on their content, grammar, and writing style.

Participants research, write, and deliver a short (2+ minute) speech on the "Employability" topic of their choice. Each participant also presents feedback to another presenter. Speeches are timed and filler words are counted.

Participants must select an employer, reach out with an introductory email, set up a meeting, and conduct a short (30-minute) interview. In these interviews, learners ask questions about the employer's perspective on what makes for a quality employee. Participants then write up the results of the interview. Writeup feedback is received.

In collaboration with the course instructor and their colleagues in the course, participants worked on the creation of updated Employability Skills materials to be presented to clients within the Missouri Department of Corrections as they begin to prepare for post-release employment.
Participants complete a detailed assessment of the course that reviews all topics and exercises covered in the eight weeks.

a0f94b33-3b30-4761-8bee-4c147b92c19b.description: This badge has been earned within the American College of Healthcare Science's Integrated Health Sciences Associates degree program, which has achieved Essential Employability Qualities Certification by Quality Assurance Commons. To earn the badge, learners engage in the activities described below. Successful completion is a grade of at least a “C” or 75%.
a0f94b33-3b30-4761-8bee-4c147b92c19b.name: Communication, ACHS

badge_template_activities.title: Successful Completion of NAT 305 Practical Coaching Simulation Project. In this semester-long project, students video-record a coaching session with a volunteer client. The student gathers feedback from the client and conducts a self-reflection. Students use this feedback to improve their communication skills during coaching sessions.

In the first module of the course, the student recruits a volunteer client and then interviews him/her using the "Wheel of Life" coaching tool, developed by the coaching leader Paul J. Meyer. The exercise, offering a 360-degree view of one's current life situation, establishes a baseline of improvement for the client and provides a flexible coaching life situation centered on creating goals and setting priorities based on one's life vision.
In Module 4 of the course, the student recruits and interviews another client and develops a health protocol for him/her. In Module 6, that volunteer client comes back for a follow-up appointment.
Learners engage in a 300-500 word written self-reflection for each interview, analyzing their strengths and weaknesses after reviewing their recordings.

Feedback for each of the interviews is provided by the client, the course instructor, and student peers. (The volunteer client completes a “Client Feedback Survey Form." The instructor and peers have reviewed a recording of the interviews.)
